Definition at line 140 of file PCA.cpp.

void PCA::rtransform ( const Array< double > &  v,
Array< double > &  w,
unsigned  maxDimA = 0 
)

Retransformation of compressed data "v" to original data "w".

Using the compressed data in v and a previously calculated transformation matrix, the original data w is reconstructed. Notice, that there is a loss of information if a dimension reduction has taken place during the previous transformation.

Parameters:
v Compressed data.
w Original data.
maxDimA Used to decrease the number of dimensions for the original data; if set to zero (= default value) the original number of dimensions will be used .
Returns:
none.
Author:
R. Alberts
Date:
2001-11-07
Changes
2003-07-18, ThB:
Dimension for resize of "w" and the limits for iteration were wrong. Bug fixed.
2002-01-30, ra:
Because of a misunderstanding, a retransformation was not possible for dimension reducted data before. This limitation was removed.

Status
stable
See also:
update
Examples:
pca_test.cpp.

Definition at line 530 of file PCA.cpp.

void PCA::setRemoveMean ( bool  flagA  ) 

If set to "true" a matrix will be created in method update, that will move the data in a way, that the mean value of the data lies in the zero-point.

setRemoveMean

Specifies, which kind of data transformation is performed at the next call of transform. A value of true means, that the mean value of the data lies in the zero-point of the coordinate system after the transformation.

Parameters:
flagA true - the mean value of the data is moved, false - the mean value of the data is left untouched.
Returns:
none
Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1998
Changes
none
Status
stable

pca_test.cpp.

Definition at line 233 of file PCA.h.

References update().

void PCA::setWhitening ( bool  flagA  ) 

If set to "true" a matrix will be created in method update, that transforms a given sequence of data to white noise.

Specifies, which kind of data transformation is performed at the next call of transform. A value of true means, that a sequence of data values is transformed into white noise, i.e. the components of each transformed data vector is uncorrelated after the whitening. Additionally, the variances of the transformed components are scaled to 1.

Parameters:
flagA true - a whitening of data is performed, false - no whitening is performed.
Returns:
none
Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1998
Changes
none
Status
stable
Examples:
pca_test.cpp.

Definition at line 242 of file PCA.cpp.

void PCA::train ( const Array< double > &  v  ) 

Calculates the estimates of the mean and the covariance matrix for the sample data "v".

The data for the estimation of the covariance and the mean matrix, that is used as base for the calculation of the transformation matrix is trained for the data in v. If v contains more than one vector, the training is performed for all data vectors.
Notice, that the transformation matrix itself is calculated only when calling method update. This separation of the calculations is done due to efficiency. Guess, you are calling the train method at different times. Then the calculation of the transformation matrix will be performed only once at the end of the last training, instead of each time, the training method is called.

Parameters:
v Data vector(s) used for training.
Returns:
none.
Exceptions:
check_exception the type of the exception will be "size mismatch" and indicates that v is not one- or 2-dimensional
Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1998
Changes
none
Status
stable
See also:
update
Examples:
pca_test.cpp.

void PCA::transform ( const Array< double > &  v,
Array< double > &  w,
unsigned  maxDimA = 0 
)

Transformation of original data "v" to compressed data "w".

Using the original data in v and a previously calculated transformation matrix, the new compressed data w is produced.

Parameters:
v Original data.
w Compressed data.
maxDimA Used to decrease the number of dimensions for the compressed data; if set to zero (= default value) the original number of dimensions will be used .

Definition at line 217 of file PCA.h.

void PCA::update (  ) 

Updates the transformation matrix.

Based on the previous modified internal structures, the transformation matrix is updated. This method will be automatically called by transform, rtransform, transMat and eigVal, so you can be sure, that you are always using the most current transformation matrix.

Returns:
none.
Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1998
Changes
2003/10/02 by S. Wiegand due to name change of 'eigensymm';
Status
stable
See also:
transform, rtransform, transMat, eigVal, train
